repo.name: weaviate
repo.description: Weaviate is an open source vector database that stores both objects and vectors, allowing for combining vector search with structured filtering with the fault-tolerance and scalability of a cloud-native database, all accessible through GraphQL, REST, and various language clients.

commits.message: marking where to connect the batched inserts
Initial changes, not tested, still some problem with the condenser exists
merging results from the queue and the index with a very basic brute force implementation
Connecting the queue to the shard (do not trigger concurrency)
ensure pending jobs are thread safe
update shard properties after successful batch indexing
disable queueLength if the feature flag is enabled

pull_request.title: async: Introduce async indexing
pull_request.body:
### What's being changed:

This PR adds support for asynchronous / batch indexing.
The idea is to allow clients to insert data as fast as possible without making them block until the data is indexed. They can then query their data before it's fully indexed, at the cost of query speed and accuracy.
We introduced an index queue that receives batches from the client, keeps them in-memory and distributes them to background indexing workers.
We also introduced a change in the HNSW index, the `AddBatch` method, which groups several inserts into one single write in the commit log.

This feature is behind a feature flag (`WEAVIATE_ASYNC_INDEXING=true`) and will mostly be tested internally for a while until we are confident it can replace the current behavior.
There are of course some corner cases that will need to be fine tuned and we are not expecting this first iteration to be the final solution.

## 🚀  Performance

### Sift

| Method                  | Import Time     | Indexing Time  |
|-------------------------|-----------------|----------------|
| Sync                    | 6m02s           |                |
| Async  | 1m39s  | 5m36s  |

### Sphere 1M

| Method                  | Import Time       | Indexing Time     |
|-------------------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| Sync                    | 33m14s            | -                 |
| Async | 9m35s | 26m32s |

## 🧑‍🔬 Differences with the current import workflow

### Before:
Currently on master, we have N main workers that are used by all the local shards to index vectors individually.
- the client sends an insert request (batch or not)
- we store the vectors in the LSM store
- each shard distributes each vector across the available workers for indexing
- we wait for all the vectors to be indexed + geoindexed (if enabled)
- we send a response to the client, with an error message for each vector, if any

### After:
Each shard has its own index queue. Each queue has its own set of dedicated workers.
- the client sends an insert request (batch or not)
- we store the vectors in the LSM store + (geoindex if enabled)
- the index queue stores the vectors in memory
- we send a response to the client
- the queue distributes chunks of the in-memory queue to its background workers (`BATCH_SIZE` parameter, default: 1000)
- each worker calls `AddBatch`

## 🔍 Search

For search queries, we merge the results of HNSW with the results of Brute force on the pending non-indexed vectors.
We limit the number of vectors passed to the Brute force algorithm (`BruteForceSearchLimit` parameter, defaul: 100k), to allow keeping a large number of vectors in memory without sacrificing too much query speed.
Once all vectors are indexed, we are expecting similar performance as before.

## ❌ Error handling

During an insert request, the client is blocking at least until the validation and persistence is done.
However, since indexing is happening in the background, we can't notify the client if an error happens.
In this PR, if an indexing error happens we simply retry indefinitely, until the indexing succeeds.
This will make the queue resilient to transient errors, but might block a worker indefinitely if the error is unrecoverable.

## 🚑  Crash recovery / startup

We keep track of indexed vectors using an optimistic approach and store that information in a BoltDB fille `index.db`.
In case of a restart or a crash, we simply iterate over objects in the LSM store, starting from that checkpoint, and enqueue vectors that are not found in the index.

##  🔥  Impact on memory / CPU

We should of course expect an increase in memory usage during imports since the queue is in-memory. There is currently no max queue size mechanism or back-pressure strategy.
With this design, it would be the user's responsibility to ensure they have enough ram to host their dataset.

## ⚙️  No configuration yet

At this stage, we don't expose any configuration to the user.
We will do so once the design is proven to be solid and we determine the right API.

## 🔬 PQ

Tested with PQ via chaos engineering pipelines

## TODO

- [x] Base implementation
- [x] Load previous vectors at startup
- [x] Search both unindexed/pending and indexed vectors
- [x] Handle deletion
- [x] Max number of vectors for brute force search 
- [x] Fix integration tests

### Review checklist

- [ ] Documentation has been updated, if necessary. Link to changed documentation:
- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:
- [x] All new code is covered by tests where it is reasonable.
- [x] Performance tests have been run or not necessary.

- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:

issue.title: async: Introduce async indexing
issue.body:
### What's being changed:

This PR adds support for asynchronous / batch indexing.
The idea is to allow clients to insert data as fast as possible without making them block until the data is indexed. They can then query their data before it's fully indexed, at the cost of query speed and accuracy.
We introduced an index queue that receives batches from the client, keeps them in-memory and distributes them to background indexing workers.
We also introduced a change in the HNSW index, the `AddBatch` method, which groups several inserts into one single write in the commit log.

This feature is behind a feature flag (`WEAVIATE_ASYNC_INDEXING=true`) and will mostly be tested internally for a while until we are confident it can replace the current behavior.
There are of course some corner cases that will need to be fine tuned and we are not expecting this first iteration to be the final solution.

## 🚀  Performance

### Sift

| Method                  | Import Time     | Indexing Time  |
|-------------------------|-----------------|----------------|
| Sync                    | 6m02s           |                |
| Async  | 1m39s  | 5m36s  |

### Sphere 1M

| Method                  | Import Time       | Indexing Time     |
|-------------------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| Sync                    | 33m14s            | -                 |
| Async | 9m35s | 26m32s |

## 🧑‍🔬 Differences with the current import workflow

### Before:
Currently on master, we have N main workers that are used by all the local shards to index vectors individually.
- the client sends an insert request (batch or not)
- we store the vectors in the LSM store
- each shard distributes each vector across the available workers for indexing
- we wait for all the vectors to be indexed + geoindexed (if enabled)
- we send a response to the client, with an error message for each vector, if any

### After:
Each shard has its own index queue. Each queue has its own set of dedicated workers.
- the client sends an insert request (batch or not)
- we store the vectors in the LSM store + (geoindex if enabled)
- the index queue stores the vectors in memory
- we send a response to the client
- the queue distributes chunks of the in-memory queue to its background workers (`BATCH_SIZE` parameter, default: 1000)
- each worker calls `AddBatch`

## 🔍 Search

For search queries, we merge the results of HNSW with the results of Brute force on the pending non-indexed vectors.
We limit the number of vectors passed to the Brute force algorithm (`BruteForceSearchLimit` parameter, defaul: 100k), to allow keeping a large number of vectors in memory without sacrificing too much query speed.
Once all vectors are indexed, we are expecting similar performance as before.

## ❌ Error handling

During an insert request, the client is blocking at least until the validation and persistence is done.
However, since indexing is happening in the background, we can't notify the client if an error happens.
In this PR, if an indexing error happens we simply retry indefinitely, until the indexing succeeds.
This will make the queue resilient to transient errors, but might block a worker indefinitely if the error is unrecoverable.

## 🚑  Crash recovery / startup

We keep track of indexed vectors using an optimistic approach and store that information in a BoltDB fille `index.db`.
In case of a restart or a crash, we simply iterate over objects in the LSM store, starting from that checkpoint, and enqueue vectors that are not found in the index.

##  🔥  Impact on memory / CPU

We should of course expect an increase in memory usage during imports since the queue is in-memory. There is currently no max queue size mechanism or back-pressure strategy.
With this design, it would be the user's responsibility to ensure they have enough ram to host their dataset.

## ⚙️  No configuration yet

At this stage, we don't expose any configuration to the user.
We will do so once the design is proven to be solid and we determine the right API.

## 🔬 PQ

Tested with PQ via chaos engineering pipelines

## TODO

- [x] Base implementation
- [x] Load previous vectors at startup
- [x] Search both unindexed/pending and indexed vectors
- [x] Handle deletion
- [x] Max number of vectors for brute force search 
- [x] Fix integration tests

### Review checklist

- [ ] Documentation has been updated, if necessary. Link to changed documentation:
- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:
- [x] All new code is covered by tests where it is reasonable.
- [x] Performance tests have been run or not necessary.

commits.message:
Merge pull request #3682 from weaviate/as/add-queue-size-to-shard-status

Add `vectorQueueSize` to `/schema/{className}/shards` response

pull_request.title: Add `vectorQueueSize` to `/schema/{className}/shards` response
pull_request.body:
### What's being changed:

Odd behaviour was observed when running Python testing of async index waiting just on the shard status alone. Sometimes, the status would be `READY` when the there were vectors in the queue ready to be indexed and thus the client would incorrectly judge the indexing to have completed.

As such, this PR adds the `vectorQueueSize` value to the endpoint so that clients can wait appropriately. _I.e.,_ they will only consider the vectors successfully loaded if `status=="READY"` and `vectorQueueSize==0`.

It also unifies some of the changes in a previous PR so that `GetShards...()` functions accept a `tenant` argument to be handled appropriately in an effort to reduce boilerplate.

@parkerduckworth please critique this as closely as possible since I made changes to many aspects of the fundamental server, e.g. clusterapi and communication between nodes. With this in mind, do these changes touch at all on the coming changes to RAFT consensus in relation to the vector queue?

### Review checklist

- [ ] Documentation has been updated, if necessary. Link to changed documentation:
- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:
- [x] All new code is covered by tests where it is reasonable.
- [ ] Performance tests have been run or not necessary.

issue.title: Error when deploying weaviate as Azure Web app

labels.name: autoclosed
labels.description: Closed by the bot. We still want this, but it didn't quite make the latest prioritization round

issue.body:
Hello,

I tried to deploy weaviate (version 1.14.0) as an Azure Web App using docker. I get this cryptic error:
`create member list: Failed to get final advertise address: No private IP address found, and explicit IP not provided`

When searching for this error, I find similar issues of other libraries that can be deployed in a cluster-way (loki, prometheus, etc.), when they are deployed to a container management service such as kubernetes or in this case azure web app. The problem seams to be, that the ip-range used within the cluster conflicts somehow with the one used by the management service. 

As I am unable to change the ip-ranges used by azure web apps, is there some config to change within weaviate?

issue.title: No private IP address found on Azure App Service
issue.body:
Trying to deploy weaviate as a simple Azure App Service and receiving the following error:

```
{
  "action": "memberlist_init",
  "bind_port": 7946,
  "error": "Failed to get final advertise address: No private IP address found, and explicit IP not provided",
  "hostname": "node1",
  "level": "error",
  "msg": "memberlist not created"
}
```

I can see a couple of other people with the same message, but no answers available. #2165 , #3100 

I am using env values from the [Starter Docker Compose file](https://weaviate.io/downloads/docker-templates/docker-compose-core.yml) and starting the container with the commands --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8080 --scheme http

Does anyone have any suggestions?

comment.body: Same issue here when using EKS

issue.title: Introduce `vector_segments_metric`
issue.body:
### What's being changed:

Currently `vector_dimensions_sum` is used for resource usage. It calculates each  non-nil `vector * dimension` in a shard. This PR creates an additional `vector_segments_sum` metric which:
- Is only exported if PQ is enabled
- Will use the segment value instead of dimensions value. This is a more accurate measure of memory usage in the case where PQ or other quantization approaches are used.
- sets `vector_dimensions_sum = 0` if enabled to allow for simple sums of metrics for usage.
- similarly to `vector_dimensions_sum` it is only enabled if `TRACK_VECTOR_DIMENSIONS` is `true`.

This PR also makes `Index.vectorIndexUserConfig` update correctly on vector index config updates.

### Example calculation
Shard having 100 non-nil vectors with dimensions 128 (note each change can take up to 5 minutes to propagate).

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=12800
```
PQ is enabled with segments = 64

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
vector_segments_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=6400
```

Alternatively suppose PQ is enabled with segments = 0, after current 5 min ticker duration:

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
vector_segments_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=12800
```

After class deleted

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
vector_segments_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
```


### Review checklist

- [ ] Documentation has been updated, if necessary. Link to changed documentation:
- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:
- [ ] All new code is covered by tests where it is reasonable.
- [ ] Performance tests have been run or not necessary.

issue.title: Introduce `vector_segments_metric`
issue.body:
### What's being changed:

Currently `vector_dimensions_sum` is used for resource usage. It calculates each  non-nil `vector * dimension` in a shard. This PR creates an additional `vector_segments_sum` metric which:
- Is only exported if PQ is enabled
- Will use the segment value instead of dimensions value. This is a more accurate measure of memory usage in the case where PQ or other quantization approaches are used.
- sets `vector_dimensions_sum = 0` if enabled to allow for simple sums of metrics for usage.
- similarly to `vector_dimensions_sum` it is only enabled if `TRACK_VECTOR_DIMENSIONS` is `true`.

This PR also makes `Index.vectorIndexUserConfig` update correctly on vector index config updates.

### Example calculation
Shard having 100 non-nil vectors with dimensions 128 (note each change can take up to 5 minutes to propagate).

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=12800
```
PQ is enabled with segments = 64

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
vector_segments_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=6400
```

Alternatively suppose PQ is enabled with segments = 0, after current 5 min ticker duration:

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
vector_segments_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=12800
```

After class deleted

```
vector_dimensions_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
vector_segments_sum{class_name=X,shard_name=Y}=0
```


### Review checklist

- [ ] Documentation has been updated, if necessary. Link to changed documentation:
- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:
- [ ] All new code is covered by tests where it is reasonable.
- [ ] Performance tests have been run or not necessary.

repo.name: weaviate
repo.description: Weaviate is an open source vector database that stores both objects and vectors, allowing for combining vector search with structured filtering with the fault-tolerance and scalability of a cloud-native database, all accessible through GraphQL, REST, and various language clients.

issue.title: [Feature Request] Add "Not" operator in filter to support "Not Like" etc. in Get queries
issue.body:
It looks like a previously faulty not operator was removed: https://github.com/weaviate/weaviate/pull/3360

But I can't see any way to filter a search by excluding some matching criteria. For example, I want to exclude embedded chunks that are from a particular domain name, so I want to essentially invert this Like:

`const response = await client.graphql
  .get()
  .withClassName('Snippet')
  .withFields('text')
  .withWhere({
    path: ['url'],
    operator: 'Like',
    valueText: 'https://example.org*',
  })
  .do();
console.log(response);`

So we'd be able to add a Not operator like this:

`const response = await client.graphql
  .get()
  .withClassName('Snippet')
  .withFields('text')
  .withWhere({
                operator: 'Not',
                operands: [{
                    path: ['url'],
                    operator: 'Like',
                    valueText: 'https://example.org*',
                }],
            })
  .do();
console.log(response);`

Given the implementation of Like etc. (https://github.com/weaviate/weaviate/blob/b5490142fa6cea9a6212e77055db7479e69760b7/adapters/repos/db/inverted/row_reader.go#L194C24-L194C24) it might actually be easier to implement as a new operator called NotLike, rather than a general purpose Not? I haven't looked too far into it.

issue.title: Switch Weaviate to go1.21
issue.body:
### What's being changed:

This PR upgrades Weaviate project Go version from `go1.20` to `go1.21`.

### Review checklist

- [ ] Documentation has been updated, if necessary. Link to changed documentation:
- [ ] Chaos pipeline run or not necessary. Link to pipeline:
- [ ] All new code is covered by tests where it is reasonable.
- [ ] Performance tests have been run or not necessary.
